urn:contentItem:6GT5-JR03-RSXG-T24M-00000-00Updated: September 08, 2025: The UAB participated in the "Manifesto for Life" initiative and other recent news2025-09-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:49ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: September 08, 2025: The UAB participated in the "Manifesto for Life" initiative and other recent news

The UAB will form part of the initiative "Manifesto for Life" proposed by the Catalan Government's Ministry for Health. The initiative forms part of the World Suicide Prevention Day, held on 10 September. Dibuix de persones abracades d'esquena

To mark World Suicide Prevention Day, which will be celebrated on 10 September, the Ministry for Health of the Government of Catalonia launches the "Manifesto for Life" initiative.

This initiative invites health centres, organisations, and citizens to join in by sharing videos of support or public readings of the manifesto on Wednesday 10 September, to raise awareness of the importance of suicide prevention and support for life.

The initiative aims to break the silence, fight the stigma, and reaffirm the collective commitment to mental health and caring for people.

The manifesto highlights that suicidal behaviour, far from being an isolated or incomprehensible act, is often the result of sustained and unbearable psychological distress, loneliness, or a lack of resources to cope with life's difficulties and find the necessary help. "Suicide is a complex and multifactorial reality, but it is also preventable," the document states.

SECTION 1 PRESS RELEASES: 2025

September 17: The UAB Healthcare Service celebrates its 50th anniversary with a tribute and recognition ceremony

The event, which brought together some one hundred people, was presided by UAB Rector Javier Lafuente, accompanied at the table by Secretary General Esther Zapater, and director of the SAS, Arantza Igartua.

Rector Lafuente welcomed the attendees and emphasised the importance of highlighting the service's track record. Esther Zapater then spoke about the fact that the SAS has been able to adapt to changing times over the course of five decades, incorporating specialties such as gynaecology, dentistry, occupational health and psychology, and demonstrating its ability to respond to critical moments such as the pandemic. The secretary general highlighted the role of proximity and humanity played by the service's staff and also gave thanks to the work carried out by the members of the First Response Teams in Emergency Situations (EPAS), who altruistically and voluntarily assist with first aid in the different UAB centres.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Join the October edition of the UAB's virtual fair for Master's Degrees, Graduate Courses and PhD Programmes

Are you looking into master's degrees and graduate courses to continue your training, specialise or reorient your professional career? Have you finished a master's degree and want to continue your academic career with a PhD? Would you like to meet and speak with the coordinator(s) of the programme that interests you? The UAB's Virtual Fair for Master's Degrees, Graduate Courses and PhD Programmes celebrates a new edition so that you can find the answers to all those questions and more. We invite you to check the complete list of sessions and register for all those that are of interest to you.

From Monday 6 to Friday 10 October 2025: five days in a row to be able to receive information about a wide range of official master's degrees, UAB-specific master's degrees, graduate courses and PhD programmes in all areas of knowledge. Around 150 information sessions, each focused on a specific study programme. The sessions consist of a short introduction made by the coordinator(s) of the study programme and then a question and answer session to clear up any doubts you may have.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention

The research-which included the participation of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB)-reveals that horses adapt their diet according to breed, environment and use. This flexibility helps them play a complementary role alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention strategies, given that their grazing reduces fuel loads and maintains open landscapes. The study was co-authored by researchers from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve.

"Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetations", explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterannean", she adds.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Sixty-four internships to explain the UAB to future UABers

If you are a UAB student and want to share your experience with others, this is your chance! We are looking for 64 undergraduate and graduate students interested in explaining the different degrees and services offered at the UAB and solve any doubts future UABers may have.

We offer three different internships, one with 60 places and two more with two places each:

The first is the Promotional activities which consists in 100 hours distributed throughout the months of January and May 2026, and focusing on student participation in activities and events, such as the Education Fair, Open Days, Family Days and other activities, both on-site and online. All of the activities can be found at the #VisitTheUAB website. Students will receive a grant of 746 euros gross in total. A total of 60 placements are offered to students from all faculties and schools, to be able to explain the wide range of academic programmes available at the UAB. You must sign up through Nexus.

September 18: Barcelona already has its first cycling map

The study is the result of a collaboration between the Institute of Environmental Science and Technology (ICTA-UAB) the Barcelona Supercomputing Center (BSC-CNS) and the Bicycle Club of Catalonia (BACC), with the fundamental support of the public: 43 volunteers collected data through the BiciZen platform, making a more detailed and possible model possible.

It is an innovative tool that allows estimating cycling traffic in more than 20,000 road sections of the city and that opens the door to a much more accurate understanding of cycling mobility patterns.

This information is key to the management of mobility in the city, since for the first time we have a detailed x-ray of cycling flows at street level. In addition, one of the great lessons learned from the project is that citizen participation has been decisive in improving the models: without crowdsourcing, today we would not have such a fine-tuned and representative map of the cycling reality.

Source: Company Website

September 17: The UAB to hold European Research Night with a full informative activities session

On Friday 26 September the UAB will celebrate European Research Night with a day full of informative activities. The aim is to bring research, innovation, and their protagonists closer to audiences of all ages in a simple and fun way. Starting at 5:00 p.m., the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona will host a research fair featuring workshops and exhibitions, games, and mini-lectures with researchers from the university and research institutes from the UAB Sphere.

The event is held each year on the last Friday of September in more than 300 cities in 30 European countries simultaneously. During the week of 22 to 26 September, more than 200 activities will be offered in Catalonia, free of charge and for all audiences, including talks, workshops, experiments, shows, and games, with the participation of researchers from more than 50 scientific institutions.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Autonomous University of Barcelona One more person from Palestine benefits from the #UABRefugi grants

A PhD student from Palestine will join the UAB in the 2025/26 academic year thanks to the #UABRefugi grants. The grants represent a comprehensive support model for refugees and now has been reinforced with a special fund to assist university students currently suffering from the armed conflict and genocide being committed by the Israeli state against the Palestinian population. A total of five people have already benefited from this aid.

The UAB programme is a comprehensive support model since the grants cover not only academic expenses, but also other costs related to materials and transport. The UAB also provides support to refugees, such as in the case of the new PhD student arriving from Palestine and his family, in terms of housing, either by reserving places at the Vila Universitaria or by working in coordination with the municipalities surrounding the campus. In addition, the UAB will launch a crowdfunding campaign among the university community to obtain new resources to support extra-academic needs such as legal advice, document translation, etc.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Autonomous University of Barcelona La Comunitaria to mark the start of the new academic year once again

On Tuesday 30 September, The Community returns for a new fall edition, from 12:00 noon to 4:00 p.m. The Bellaterra campus will host activities, shows, experiences, and much more. The event is an opportunity to get to know the UAB's network of associations, learn, and enjoy a unique day.

The opening speech, in the Placa del Coneixement, will kick off the 2025 fall edition of La Comunitaria. And once the day begins, attendees will be able to enjoy the entites' fair which offers a wide range of activities organised by the different groups, student councils, and services that form part of the University and enrich the UAB.

In addition, Placa del Coneixement will host various shows and performances, such as the traditional human towers by the Ganapies and sardana dancing by the Agrupacio Sardanista de Cerdanyola del Valles. It should be noted that this year's event coincides with the 25th anniversary of the UAB Solidarity Foundation (FAS), with activities to commemorate the anniversary.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Twelve UAB projects selected to study and improve emotional wellbeing at universities

Twelve UAB research projects have been selected by AGAUR in a second call for the development of projects with social impacts. The projects must take on challenges related to mental health and emotional wellbeing at universities and other entities of the research and innovation system.

The selected projects cover disciplines such as clinical and health psychology, veterinary medicine, physics, nursing, social psychology, and anthropology, and will address different subjects of study. The aim is to obtain data and provide solutions for the emotional wellbeing of all members of the university community, which in turn can be extrapolated and sustained over time. The total amount obtained to conduct these studies is EUR220,000.

All selected studies will be carried out in coordination between the research groups involved, with the collaboration of the UAB's CORE in Mental Health network and the Equality and Diversity Service. The main project will be carried out by the Equality and Diversity Service, under the title "Recursos per a la promocio del benestar emocional i l'autocura per a la comunitat de la UAB: sensibilitzacio, punts blaus i grups d'ajuda mutua" [Resources for promoting emotional wellbeing and self-care for the UAB community: awareness-raising, blue points, and mutual support groups].

September 10: Autonomous University of Barcelona: R7 Cercanias abolition from November 2025 to May 2026

The works at the Montcada Bifurcacio station will involve the removal of the R7 line for 7 months. 100925_Supressio R7

The works being carried out by Adif in Montcada i Reixac will affect the service of the R2 Norte, R2 Sur, R7, and R11 commuter train lines. The remodeling of the tracks and the installation of a new traffic management system will mean the elimination of the R7 line between November 2, 2025, and May 15, 2026.

To guarantee the right to mobility, Renfe will offer an alternative bus service between the Cerdanyola stations, which can still be reached by the R4 line, and the Campus.

The schedules for this service and the exact stop locations will be available in the coming weeks.

Source: Company Website

September 10: The third training programme for UAB staff in 2025 includes more than 110 activities

The UAB has published its third continuing education programme for 2025, aimed at both teaching and research staff (PDI) and technical, management, administrative, and service staff (PTGAS). This new programme includes more than 110 training activities that can be completed until 30 January 2026. The deadline for submitting applications is 19 September. Young man working on the computer Young man working on the computer

The programmes offered have been designed to meet the professional needs of both teaching and research staff and administrative and technical staff, with a wide variety of topics, formats, and schedules (to facilitate work-life balance, afternoon training and asynchronous virtual modalities are included). Some activities are aimed at both groups, such as those related to gender perspective, digital skills, occupational risk prevention, and research projects. These common lines respond to cross-cutting areas of institutional and professional development.

Source: Company Website

September 10: The UAB promotes language learning as a path to more training, research and socialisation

The UAB offers language courses for international students studying at the UAB so that they can become familiar with the Catalan language, and also for UAB students thinking of studying abroad, to learn the language of the country they will visit. Languages are key to opening the doors of both academic learning and research activities, as well as being able to communicate in everyday life situations and understanding the local culture. The similarity among the different Romance languages also makes it easier for those who speak one of these languages, to quickly learn to speak another one. La UAB de les llengues

On the one hand, the Languages Service - UAB Idiomes offers a wide array of courses in many of the languages spoken in the countries where UAB students go to study abroad. These courses help them improve academically and live the university experience abroad to the fullest. Mastering a new language also contributes to creating more research collaborations and advancing towards a science without borders.

Source: Company Website

September 10: Autonomous University of Barcelona: One billion euros for the technological transformation of the Alba Synchrotron

The Government of Catalonia and the Spanish Ministry for Science, Innovation, and Universities have signed an agreement establishing a joint contribution of nearly one billion euros until 2038 to transform the Alba Synchrotron into a fourth-generation synchrotron light infrastructure. The agreement was presented at an institutional event attended by UAB Rector Javier Lafuente. Sincrotro Alba

Diana Mirant, minister for Science, Innovation, and Universities, and Salvador Illa, president of the Government of Catalonia, recently signed an agreement establishing a joint contribution of over EUR926 million over the 2025-2038 period to transform the Alba Synchrotron into a fourth-generation synchrotron light infrastructure. The total contributions made by the Catalan government will amount to almost EUR465 million over the agreed period. The Ministry Spanish for Science, Innovation, and Universities has committed to spending EUR461 million.

Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6GT5-JR03-RSXG-T24K-00000-00Updated: September 08, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Seminar on digital violence and deepfakes and other recent news2025-09-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:49ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: September 08, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Seminar on digital violence and deepfakes and other recent news

The Faculty of Law of the UAB will host the seminar 'Digital Violence and Deepfakes: Challenges for European and Italian Criminal Law' next 25 September at 5:00 p.m. in the Board Room (Sala de juntes). Seminari Violencia Digital

The session will feature interventions from Dr Costanza Bernasconi (University of Ferrara), who will analyse the role of Directive (EU) 2024/1385 in the fight against digital violence, and Dr Caterina Paonessa (University of Florence), who will address the challenges of criminal law regarding deepfakes from an Italian and European perspective.

The activity is organised by the Criminal Law and Criminology Unit of the Faculty of Law at the UAB and will also be available online through Teams with prior registration. To do this, interested students must contact Professor Joan Baucells (joan.baucells@uab.cat) before Tuesday 23 September, to receive the link.

September 17: The UAB Healthcare Service celebrates its 50th anniversary with a tribute and recognition ceremony

The event, which brought together some one hundred people, was presided by UAB Rector Javier Lafuente, accompanied at the table by Secretary General Esther Zapater, and director of the SAS, Arantza Igartua.

Rector Lafuente welcomed the attendees and emphasised the importance of highlighting the service 's track record. Esther Zapater then spoke about the fact that the SAS has been able to adapt to changing times over the course of five decades, incorporating specialties such as gynaecology, dentistry, occupational health and psychology, and demonstrating its ability to respond to critical moments such as the pandemic. The secretary general highlighted the role of proximity and humanity played by the service's staff and also gave thanks to the work carried out by the members of the First Response Teams in Emergency Situations (EPAS), who altruistically and voluntarily assist with first aid in the different UAB centres.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Join the October edition of the UAB's virtual fair for Master's Degrees, Graduate Courses and PhD Programmes

Are you looking into master's degrees and graduate courses to continue your training, specialise or reorient your professional career? Have you finished a master's degree and want to continue your academic career with a PhD? Would you like to meet and speak with the coordinator(s) of the programme that interests you? The UAB's Virtual Fair for Master's Degrees, Graduate Courses and PhD Programmes celebrates a new edition so that you can find the answers to all those questions and more. We invite you to check the complete list of sessions and register for all those that are of interest to you.

From Monday 6 to Friday 10 October 2025: five days in a row to be able to receive information about a wide range of official master's degrees, UAB-specific master's degrees, graduate courses and PhD programmes in all areas of knowledge. Around 150 information sessions, each focused on a specific study programme. The sessions consist of a short introduction made by the coordinator(s) of the study programme and then a question and answer session to clear up any doubts you may have.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention

The research-which included the participation of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB)-reveals that horses adapt their diet according to breed, environment and use. This flexibility helps them play a complementary role alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention strategies, given that their grazing reduces fuel loads and maintains open landscapes. The study was co-authored by researchers from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve.

"Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetations", explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterannean", she adds.

Source: Company Website

If you are a UAB student and want to share your experience with others, this is your chance! We are looking for 64 undergraduate and graduate students interested in explaining the different degrees and services offered at the UAB and solve any doubts future UABers may have.

The first is the Promotional activities which consists in 100 hours distributed throughout the months of January and May 2026, and focusing on student participation in activities and events, such as the Education Fair, Open Days, Family Days and other activities, both on-site and online. All of the activities can be found at the #VisitTheUAB website. Students will receive a grant of 746 euros gross in total. A total of 60 placements are offered to students from all faculties and schools, to be able to explain the wide range of academic programmes available at the UAB. You must sign up through Nexus.

September 18: Barcelona already has its first cycling map

The study is the result of a collaboration between the Institute of Environmental Science and Technology (ICTA-UAB) the Barcelona Supercomputing Center (BSC-CNS) and the Bicycle Club of Catalonia (BACC), with the fundamental support of the public: 43 volunteers collected data through the BiciZen platform, making a more detailed and possible model possible.

It is an innovative tool that allows estimating cycling traffic in more than 20,000 road sections of the city and that opens the door to a much more accurate understanding of cycling mobility patterns.

This information is key to the management of mobility in the city, since for the first time we have a detailed x-ray of cycling flows at street level. In addition, one of the great lessons learned from the project is that citizen participation has been decisive in improving the models: without crowdsourcing, today we would not have such a fine-tuned and representative map of the cycling reality.

Source: Company Website

September 17: The UAB to hold European Research Night with a full informative activities session

On Friday 26 September the UAB will celebrate European Research Night with a day full of informative activities. The aim is to bring research, innovation, and their protagonists closer to audiences of all ages in a simple and fun way. Starting at 5:00 p.m., the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona will host a research fair featuring workshops and exhibitions, games, and mini-lectures with researchers from the university and research institutes from the UAB Sphere.

The event is held each year on the last Friday of September in more than 300 cities in 30 European countries simultaneously. During the week of 22 to 26 September, more than 200 activities will be offered in Catalonia, free of charge and for all audiences, including talks, workshops, experiments, shows, and games, with the participation of researchers from more than 50 scientific institutions.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Autonomous University of Barcelona One more person from Palestine benefits from the #UABRefugi grants

A PhD student from Palestine will join the UAB in the 2025/26 academic year thanks to the #UABRefugi grants. The grants represent a comprehensive support model for refugees and now has been reinforced with a special fund to assist university students currently suffering from the armed conflict and genocide being committed by the Israeli state against the Palestinian population. A total of five people have already benefited from this aid.

The UAB programme is a comprehensive support model since the grants cover not only academic expenses, but also other costs related to materials and transport. The UAB also provides support to refugees, such as in the case of the new PhD student arriving from Palestine and his family, in terms of housing, either by reserving places at the Vila Universitaria or by working in coordination with the municipalities surrounding the campus. In addition, the UAB will launch a crowdfunding campaign among the university community to obtain new resources to support extra-academic needs such as legal advice, document translation, etc.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Autonomous University of Barcelona La Comunitaria to mark the start of the new academic year once again

On Tuesday 30 September, The Community returns for a new fall edition, from 12:00 noon to 4:00 p.m. The Bellaterra campus will host activities, shows, experiences, and much more. The event is an opportunity to get to know the UAB's network of associations, learn, and enjoy a unique day.

The opening speech, in the Placa del Coneixement, will kick off the 2025 fall edition of La Comunitaria. And once the day begins, attendees will be able to enjoy the entites' fair which offers a wide range of activities organised by the different groups, student councils, and services that form part of the University and enrich the UAB.

In addition, Placa del Coneixement will host various shows and performances, such as the traditional human towers by the Ganapies and sardana dancing by the Agrupacio Sardanista de Cerdanyola del Valles. It should be noted that this year's event coincides with the 25th anniversary of the UAB Solidarity Foundation (FAS), with activities to commemorate the anniversary.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Twelve UAB projects selected to study and improve emotional wellbeing at universities

Twelve UAB research projects have been selected by AGAUR in a second call for the development of projects with social impacts. The projects must take on challenges related to mental health and emotional wellbeing at universities and other entities of the research and innovation system.

The selected projects cover disciplines such as clinical and health psychology, veterinary medicine, physics, nursing, social psychology, and anthropology, and will address different subjects of study. The aim is to obtain data and provide solutions for the emotional wellbeing of all members of the university community, which in turn can be extrapolated and sustained over time. The total amount obtained to conduct these studies is EUR220,000.

All selected studies will be carried out in coordination between the research groups involved, with the collaboration of the UAB's CORE in Mental Health network and the Equality and Diversity Service. The main project will be carried out by the Equality and Diversity Service, under the title "Recursos per a la promocio del benestar emocional i l'autocura per a la comunitat de la UAB: sensibilitzacio, punts blaus i grups d'ajuda mutua" [Resources for promoting emotional wellbeing and self-care for the UAB community: awareness-raising, blue points, and mutual support groups].

September 10: Autonomous University of Barcelona: R7 Cercanias abolition from November 2025 to May 2026

The works at the Montcada Bifurcacio station will involve the removal of the R7 line for 7 months. 100925_Supressio R7

The works being carried out by Adif in Montcada i Reixac will affect the service of the R2 Norte, R2 Sur, R7, and R11 commuter train lines. The remodeling of the tracks and the installation of a new traffic management system will mean the elimination of the R7 line between November 2, 2025, and May 15, 2026.

To guarantee the right to mobility, Renfe will offer an alternative bus service between the Cerdanyola stations, which can still be reached by the R4 line, and the Campus.

The schedules for this service and the exact stop locations will be available in the coming weeks.

Source: Company Website

September 10: The third training programme for UAB staff in 2025 includes more than 110 activities

The UAB has published its third continuing education programme for 2025, aimed at both teaching and research staff (PDI) and technical, management, administrative, and service staff (PTGAS). This new programme includes more than 110 training activities that can be completed until 30 January 2026. The deadline for submitting applications is 19 September. Young man working on the computer Young man working on the computer

The programmes offered have been designed to meet the professional needs of both teaching and research staff and administrative and technical staff, with a wide variety of topics, formats, and schedules (to facilitate work-life balance, afternoon training and asynchronous virtual modalities are included). Some activities are aimed at both groups, such as those related to gender perspective, digital skills, occupational risk prevention, and research projects. These common lines respond to cross-cutting areas of institutional and professional development.

Source: Company Website

September 10: The UAB promotes language learning as a path to more training, research and socialisation

The UAB offers language courses for international students studying at the UAB so that they can become familiar with the Catalan language, and also for UAB students thinking of studying abroad, to learn the language of the country they will visit. Languages are key to opening the doors of both academic learning and research activities, as well as being able to communicate in everyday life situations and understanding the local culture. The similarity among the different Romance languages also makes it easier for those who speak one of these languages, to quickly learn to speak another one. La UAB de les llengues

On the one hand, the Languages Service - UAB Idiomes offers a wide array of courses in many of the languages spoken in the countries where UAB students go to study abroad. These courses help them improve academically and live the university experience abroad to the fullest. Mastering a new language also contributes to creating more research collaborations and advancing towards a science without borders.

Source: Company Website

September 10: Autonomous University of Barcelona: One billion euros for the technological transformation of the Alba Synchrotron

The Government of Catalonia and the Spanish Ministry for Science, Innovation, and Universities have signed an agreement establishing a joint contribution of nearly one billion euros until 2038 to transform the Alba Synchrotron into a fourth-generation synchrotron light infrastructure. The agreement was presented at an institutional event attended by UAB Rector Javier Lafuente. Sincrotro Alba

Diana Mirant, minister for Science, Innovation, and Universities, and Salvador Illa, president of the Government of Catalonia, recently signed an agreement establishing a joint contribution of over EUR926 million over the 2025-2038 period to transform the Alba Synchrotron into a fourth-generation synchrotron light infrastructure. The total contributions made by the Catalan government will amount to almost EUR465 million over the agreed period. The Ministry Spanish for Science, Innovation, and Universities has committed to spending EUR461 million.

Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6GT5-JR03-RSXG-T24J-00000-00Updated: September 05, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Improvements to intercity bus services for the 2025-2026 academic year and other recent news2025-09-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:49ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: September 05, 2025: Autonomous University of Barcelona: Improvements to intercity bus services for the 2025-2026 academic year and other recent news

Improvements to the Barcelona-Cerdanyola-UAB, Sabadell-Barbera-Badia-UAB, Mataro-Argentona-UAB, Igualada-Martorell-UAB and Montcada-Ripollet-UAB lines 050925_Millora linies bus interurba 25_26

Starting September 8, 2025, the Generalitat de Catalunya (Catalan government) will add millions of euros to five of the lines that will connect the UAB Campus with some municipalities. Barcelona-Cerdanyola-UAB Since September 22, the Barcelona-Cerdanyola-UAB line offers a total of 204 journeys between Barcelona and the UAB Campus, from Monday to Friday, between 6:00 a.m. and 10:40 p.m. The total increase compared to the previous service is 54 journeys per day. It is worth highlighting the increase in Barcelona-UAB journeys from 4 to 27 per day, which will entail a significant reduction in travel time. You can find more details on the operator's website: www.moventis.es Sabadell-Barbera-Badia-UAB Since September 22, the Sabadell-Barbera-Badia-UAB line offers a total of 16 journeys per year and return between Sabadell and the University Campus from Monday to Friday, between 6:45 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. The total increase compared to the previous service is 12 journeys during the day.

September 17: The UAB Healthcare Service celebrates its 50th anniversary with a tribute and recognition ceremony

The event, which brought together some one hundred people, was presided by UAB Rector Javier Lafuente, accompanied at the table by Secretary General Esther Zapater, and director of the SAS, Arantza Igartua.

Rector Lafuente welcomed the attendees and emphasised the importance of highlighting the service's track record. Esther Zapater then spoke about the fact that the SAS has been able to adapt to changing times over the course of five decades, incorporating specialties such as gynaecology, dentistry, occupational health and psychology, and demonstrating its ability to respond to critical moments such as the pandemic. The secretary general highlighted the role of proximity and humanity played by the service's staff and also gave thanks to the work carried out by the members of the First Response Teams in Emergency Situations (EPAS), who altruistically and voluntarily assist with first aid in the different UAB centres.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Join the October edition of the UAB's virtual fair for Master's Degrees, Graduate Courses and PhD Programmes

Are you looking into master's degrees and graduate courses to continue your training, specialise or reorient your professional career? Have you finished a master's degree and want to continue your academic career with a PhD? Would you like to meet and speak with the coordinator(s) of the programme that interests you? The UAB's Virtual Fair for Master's Degrees, Graduate Courses and PhD Programmes celebrates a new edition so that you can find the answers to all those questions and more. We invite you to check the complete list of sessions and register for all those that are of interest to you.

From Monday 6 to Friday 10 October 2025: five days in a row to be able to receive information about a wide range of official master's degrees, UAB-specific master's degrees, graduate courses and PhD programmes in all areas of knowledge. Around 150 information sessions, each focused on a specific study programme. The sessions consist of a short introduction made by the coordinator(s) of the study programme and then a question and answer session to clear up any doubts you may have.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention

The research-which included the participation of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB)-reveals that horses adapt their diet according to breed, environment and use. This flexibility helps them play a complementary role alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention strategies, given that their grazing reduces fuel loads and maintains open landscapes. The study was co-authored by researchers from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve.

"Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetations", explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterannean", she adds.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Sixty-four internships to explain the UAB to future UABers

If you are a UAB student and want to share your experience with others, this is your chance! We are looking for 64 undergraduate and graduate students interested in explaining the different degrees and services offered at the UAB and solve any doubts future UABers may have.

We offer three different internships, one with 60 places and two more with two places each:

The first is the Promotional activities which consists in 100 hours distributed throughout the months of January and May 2026, and focusing on student participation in activities and events, such as the Education Fair, Open Days, Family Days and other activities, both on-site and online. All of the activities can be found at the #VisitTheUAB website. Students will receive a grant of 746 euros gross in total. A total of 60 placements are offered to students from all faculties and schools, to be able to explain the wide range of academic programmes available at the UAB. You must sign up through Nexus.

September 18: Barcelona already has its first cycling map

The study is the result of a collaboration between the Institute of Environmental Science and Technology (ICTA-UAB) the Barcelona Supercomputing Center (BSC-CNS) and the Bicycle Club of Catalonia (BACC), with the fundamental support of the public: 43 volunteers collected data through the BiciZen platform, making a more detailed and possible model possible.

It is an innovative tool that allows estimating cycling traffic in more than 20,000 road sections of the city and that opens the door to a much more accurate understanding of cycling mobility patterns.

This information is key to the management of mobility in the city, since for the first time we have a detailed x-ray of cycling flows at street level. In addition, one of the great lessons learned from the project is that citizen participation has been decisive in improving the models: without crowdsourcing, today we would not have such a fine-tuned and representative map of the cycling reality.

Source: Company Website

September 17: The UAB to hold European Research Night with a full informative activities session

On Friday 26 September the UAB will celebrate European Research Night with a day full of informative activities. The aim is to bring research, innovation, and their protagonists closer to audiences of all ages in a simple and fun way. Starting at 5:00 p.m., the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona will host a research fair featuring workshops and exhibitions, games, and mini-lectures with researchers from the university and research institutes from the UAB Sphere.

The event is held each year on the last Friday of September in more than 300 cities in 30 European countries simultaneously. During the week of 22 to 26 September, more than 200 activities will be offered in Catalonia, free of charge and for all audiences, including talks, workshops, experiments, shows, and games, with the participation of researchers from more than 50 scientific institutions.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Autonomous University of Barcelona One more person from Palestine benefits from the #UABRefugi grants

A PhD student from Palestine will join the UAB in the 2025/26 academic year thanks to the #UABRefugi grants. The grants represent a comprehensive support model for refugees and now has been reinforced with a special fund to assist university students currently suffering from the armed conflict and genocide being committed by the Israeli state against the Palestinian population. A total of five people have already benefited from this aid.

The UAB programme is a comprehensive support model since the grants cover not only academic expenses, but also other costs related to materials and transport. The UAB also provides support to refugees, such as in the case of the new PhD student arriving from Palestine and his family, in terms of housing, either by reserving places at the Vila Universitaria or by working in coordination with the municipalities surrounding the campus. In addition, the UAB will launch a crowdfunding campaign among the university community to obtain new resources to support extra-academic needs such as legal advice, document translation, etc.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Autonomous University of Barcelona La Comunitaria to mark the start of the new academic year once again

On Tuesday 30 September, The Community returns for a new fall edition, from 12:00 noon to 4:00 p.m. The Bellaterra campus will host activities, shows, experiences, and much more. The event is an opportunity to get to know the UAB's network of associations, learn, and enjoy a unique day.

The opening speech, in the Placa del Coneixement, will kick off the 2025 fall edition of La Comunitaria. And once the day begins, attendees will be able to enjoy the entites' fair which offers a wide range of activities organised by the different groups, student councils, and services that form part of the University and enrich the UAB.

In addition, Placa del Coneixement will host various shows and performances, such as the traditional human towers by the Ganapies and sardana dancing by the Agrupacio Sardanista de Cerdanyola del Valles. It should be noted that this year's event coincides with the 25th anniversary of the UAB Solidarity Foundation (FAS), with activities to commemorate the anniversary.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Twelve UAB projects selected to study and improve emotional wellbeing at universities

Twelve UAB research projects have been selected by AGAUR in a second call for the development of projects with social impacts. The projects must take on challenges related to mental health and emotional wellbeing at universities and other entities of the research and innovation system.

The selected projects cover disciplines such as clinical and health psychology, veterinary medicine, physics, nursing, social psychology, and anthropology, and will address different subjects of study. The aim is to obtain data and provide solutions for the emotional wellbeing of all members of the university community, which in turn can be extrapolated and sustained over time. The total amount obtained to conduct these studies is EUR220,000.

All selected studies will be carried out in coordination between the research groups involved, with the collaboration of the UAB's CORE in Mental Health network and the Equality and Diversity Service. The main project will be carried out by the Equality and Diversity Service, under the title "Recursos per a la promocio del benestar emocional i l'autocura per a la comunitat de la UAB: sensibilitzacio, punts blaus i grups d'ajuda mutua" [Resources for promoting emotional wellbeing and self-care for the UAB community: awareness-raising, blue points, and mutual support groups].

September 10: Autonomous University of Barcelona: R7 Cercanias abolition from November 2025 to May 2026

The works at the Montcada Bifurcacio station will involve the removal of the R7 line for 7 months. 100925_Supressio R7

The works being carried out by Adif in Montcada i Reixac will affect the service of the R2 Norte, R2 Sur, R7, and R11 commuter train lines. The remodeling of the tracks and the installation of a new traffic management system will mean the elimination of the R7 line between November 2, 2025, and May 15, 2026.

To guarantee the right to mobility, Renfe will offer an alternative bus service between the Cerdanyola stations, which can still be reached by the R4 line, and the Campus.

The schedules for this service and the exact stop locations will be available in the coming weeks.

Source: Company Website

September 10: The third training programme for UAB staff in 2025 includes more than 110 activities

The UAB has published its third continuing education programme for 2025, aimed at both teaching and research staff (PDI) and technical, management, administrative, and service staff (PTGAS). This new programme includes more than 110 training activities that can be completed until 30 January 2026. The deadline for submitting applications is 19 September. Young man working on the computer Young man working on the computer

The programmes offered have been designed to meet the professional needs of both teaching and research staff and administrative and technical staff, with a wide variety of topics, formats, and schedules (to facilitate work-life balance, afternoon training and asynchronous virtual modalities are included). Some activities are aimed at both groups, such as those related to gender perspective, digital skills, occupational risk prevention, and research projects. These common lines respond to cross-cutting areas of institutional and professional development.

Source: Company Website

September 10: The UAB promotes language learning as a path to more training, research and socialisation

The UAB offers language courses for international students studying at the UAB so that they can become familiar with the Catalan language, and also for UAB students thinking of studying abroad, to learn the language of the country they will visit. Languages are key to opening the doors of both academic learning and research activities, as well as being able to communicate in everyday life situations and understanding the local culture. The similarity among the different Romance languages also makes it easier for those who speak one of these languages, to quickly learn to speak another one. La UAB de les llengues

On the one hand, the Languages Service - UAB Idiomes offers a wide array of courses in many of the languages spoken in the countries where UAB students go to study abroad. These courses help them improve academically and live the university experience abroad to the fullest. Mastering a new language also contributes to creating more research collaborations and advancing towards a science without borders.

Source: Company Website

September 10: Autonomous University of Barcelona: One billion euros for the technological transformation of the Alba Synchrotron

The Government of Catalonia and the Spanish Ministry for Science, Innovation, and Universities have signed an agreement establishing a joint contribution of nearly one billion euros until 2038 to transform the Alba Synchrotron into a fourth-generation synchrotron light infrastructure. The agreement was presented at an institutional event attended by UAB Rector Javier Lafuente. Sincrotro Alba

Diana Mirant, minister for Science, Innovation, and Universities, and Salvador Illa, president of the Government of Catalonia, recently signed an agreement establishing a joint contribution of over EUR926 million over the 2025-2038 period to transform the Alba Synchrotron into a fourth-generation synchrotron light infrastructure. The total contributions made by the Catalan government will amount to almost EUR465 million over the agreed period. The Ministry Spanish for Science, Innovation, and Universities has committed to spending EUR461 million.

urn:contentItem:6GT5-JR03-RSXG-T24G-00000-00Updated: September 09, 2025: Enrolment now open for the UAB's 2025/26 language courses and other recent news2025-09-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:49ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSUpdated: September 09, 2025: Enrolment now open for the UAB's 2025/26 language courses and other recent news

The Languages Service - UAB Idiomes Campus offers a variety of language courses that adapt to the academic and professional needs of members of the UAB community. The enrolment period for language courses offered this 2025/26 academic year is now open. Oberta la matricula als cursos de llengues 2025-2026

English courses are offered from levels A2 to C2.1 of the Common European Framework of Reference, as well as preparation courses for the B1, B2, and C1 exams, and specific courses for UAB academic staff and PhD students. Many courses offer the option of attending in person or via videoconference.

Among other foreign languages, face-to-face courses are offered in French (levels A1 to B2.2), German (levels A1 to B1), and Italian (levels A1 and A2). In addition, there are classroom-based courses in Catalan from levels A2 to C2, distance learning courses at levels C1 and C2, and beginner courses for exchange students. As for Spanish, classroom-based courses are offered from levels A1 to B2.2.

September 17: The UAB Healthcare Service celebrates its 50th anniversary with a tribute and recognition ceremony

The event, which brought together some one hundred people, was presided by UAB Rector Javier Lafuente, accompanied at the table by Secretary General Esther Zapater, and director of the SAS, Arantza Igartua.

Rector Lafuente welcomed the attendees and emphasised the importance of highlighting the service's track record. Esther Zapater then spoke about the fact that the SAS has been able to adapt to changing times over the course of five decades, incorporating specialties such as gynaecology, dentistry, occupational health and psychology, and demonstrating its ability to respond to critical moments such as the pandemic. The secretary general highlighted the role of proximity and humanity played by the service's staff and also gave thanks to the work carried out by the members of the First Response Teams in Emergency Situations (EPAS), who altruistically and voluntarily assist with first aid in the different UAB centres.

September 18: Join the October edition of the UAB's virtual fair for Master's Degrees, Graduate Courses and PhD Programmes

Are you looking into master's degrees and graduate courses to continue your training, specialise or reorient your professional career? Have you finished a master's degree and want to continue your academic career with a PhD? Would you like to meet and speak with the coordinator(s) of the programme that interests you? The UAB's Virtual Fair for Master's Degrees, Graduate Courses and PhD Programmes celebrates a new edition so that you can find the answers to all those questions and more. We invite you to check the complete list of sessions and register for all those that are of interest to you.

From Monday 6 to Friday 10 October 2025: five days in a row to be able to receive information about a wide range of official master's degrees, UAB-specific master's degrees, graduate courses and PhD programmes in all areas of knowledge. Around 150 information sessions, each focused on a specific study programme. The sessions consist of a short introduction made by the coordinator(s) of the study programme and then a question and answer session to clear up any doubts you may have.

September 18: Autonomous University of Barcelona Horses, possible allies in forest fire prevention

The research-which included the participation of Boumort Wildland, the Miranda Foundation, the Forest Horses association, and the University of Barcelona (UB)-reveals that horses adapt their diet according to breed, environment and use. This flexibility helps them play a complementary role alongside other herbivores in sustainable fire prevention strategies, given that their grazing reduces fuel loads and maintains open landscapes. The study was co-authored by researchers from the Department of Animal and Food Science at the UAB Jordi Bartolome and Araceli Gort-Esteve.

"Until now research on extensive herding and forest fire prevention has focused mainly on sheep and goats, with some isolated studies done on breeds of rustic cattle. There have been very few studies on horses within this context, since traditionally they are classified as plant grazers that have little effect on woody vegetations", explains Ariadna Nieto-Espinet, Ramon y Cajal researcher at the UdL and zooarchaeologist. "Our work is one of the first to use empirical data to analyse their potential in forest management in the Mediterannean", she adds.

Source: Company Website

September 18: Barcelona already has its first cycling map

The study is the result of a collaboration between the Institute of Environmental Science and Technology (ICTA-UAB) the Barcelona Supercomputing Center (BSC-CNS) and the Bicycle Club of Catalonia (BACC), with the fundamental support of the public: 43 volunteers collected data through the BiciZen platform, making a more detailed and possible model possible.

It is an innovative tool that allows estimating cycling traffic in more than 20,000 road sections of the city and that opens the door to a much more accurate understanding of cycling mobility patterns.

This information is key to the management of mobility in the city, since for the first time we have a detailed x-ray of cycling flows at street level. In addition, one of the great lessons learned from the project is that citizen participation has been decisive in improving the models: without crowdsourcing, today we would not have such a fine-tuned and representative map of the cycling reality.

Source: Company Website

September 17: The UAB to hold European Research Night with a full informative activities session

On Friday 26 September the UAB will celebrate European Research Night with a day full of informative activities. The aim is to bring research, innovation, and their protagonists closer to audiences of all ages in a simple and fun way. Starting at 5:00 p.m., the Universitat Autonoma de Barcelona will host a research fair featuring workshops and exhibitions, games, and mini-lectures with researchers from the university and research institutes from the UAB Sphere.

The event is held each year on the last Friday of September in more than 300 cities in 30 European countries simultaneously. During the week of 22 to 26 September, more than 200 activities will be offered in Catalonia, free of charge and for all audiences, including talks, workshops, experiments, shows, and games, with the participation of researchers from more than 50 scientific institutions.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Autonomous University of Barcelona One more person from Palestine benefits from the #UABRefugi grants

A PhD student from Palestine will join the UAB in the 2025/26 academic year thanks to the #UABRefugi grants. The grants represent a comprehensive support model for refugees and now has been reinforced with a special fund to assist university students currently suffering from the armed conflict and genocide being committed by the Israeli state against the Palestinian population. A total of five people have already benefited from this aid.

The UAB programme is a comprehensive support model since the grants cover not only academic expenses, but also other costs related to materials and transport. The UAB also provides support to refugees, such as in the case of the new PhD student arriving from Palestine and his family, in terms of housing, either by reserving places at the Vila Universitaria or by working in coordination with the municipalities surrounding the campus. In addition, the UAB will launch a crowdfunding campaign among the university community to obtain new resources to support extra-academic needs such as legal advice, document translation, etc.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Autonomous University of Barcelona La Comunitaria to mark the start of the new academic year once again

On Tuesday 30 September, The Community returns for a new fall edition, from 12:00 noon to 4:00 p.m. The Bellaterra campus will host activities, shows, experiences, and much more. The event is an opportunity to get to know the UAB's network of associations, learn, and enjoy a unique day.

The opening speech, in the Placa del Coneixement, will kick off the 2025 fall edition of La Comunitaria. And once the day begins, attendees will be able to enjoy the entites' fair which offers a wide range of activities organised by the different groups, student councils, and services that form part of the University and enrich the UAB.

In addition, Placa del Coneixement will host various shows and performances, such as the traditional human towers by the Ganapies and sardana dancing by the Agrupacio Sardanista de Cerdanyola del Valles. It should be noted that this year's event coincides with the 25th anniversary of the UAB Solidarity Foundation (FAS), with activities to commemorate the anniversary.

Source: Company Website

September 17: Twelve UAB projects selected to study and improve emotional wellbeing at universities

Twelve UAB research projects have been selected by AGAUR in a second call for the development of projects with social impacts. The projects must take on challenges related to mental health and emotional wellbeing at universities and other entities of the research and innovation system.

The selected projects cover disciplines such as clinical and health psychology, veterinary medicine, physics, nursing, social psychology, and anthropology, and will address different subjects of study. The aim is to obtain data and provide solutions for the emotional wellbeing of all members of the university community, which in turn can be extrapolated and sustained over time. The total amount obtained to conduct these studies is EUR220,000.

All selected studies will be carried out in coordination between the research groups involved, with the collaboration of the UAB's CORE in Mental Health network and the Equality and Diversity Service. The main project will be carried out by the Equality and Diversity Service, under the title "Recursos per a la promocio del benestar emocional i l'autocura per a la comunitat de la UAB: sensibilitzacio, punts blaus i grups d'ajuda mutua" [Resources for promoting emotional wellbeing and self-care for the UAB community: awareness-raising, blue points, and mutual support groups].

September 10: Autonomous University of Barcelona: R7 Cercanias abolition from November 2025 to May 2026

The works at the Montcada Bifurcacio station will involve the removal of the R7 line for 7 months. 100925_Supressio R7

The works being carried out by Adif in Montcada i Reixac will affect the service of the R2 Norte, R2 Sur, R7, and R11 commuter train lines. The remodeling of the tracks and the installation of a new traffic management system will mean the elimination of the R7 line between November 2, 2025, and May 15, 2026.

To guarantee the right to mobility, Renfe will offer an alternative bus service between the Cerdanyola stations, which can still be reached by the R4 line, and the Campus.

The schedules for this service and the exact stop locations will be available in the coming weeks.

September 10: The third training programme for UAB staff in 2025 includes more than 110 activities

The UAB has published its third continuing education programme for 2025, aimed at both teaching and research staff (PDI) and technical, management, administrative, and service staff (PTGAS). This new programme includes more than 110 training activities that can be completed until 30 January 2026. The deadline for submitting applications is 19 September. Young man working on the computer Young man working on the computer

The programmes offered have been designed to meet the professional needs of both teaching and research staff and administrative and technical staff, with a wide variety of topics, formats, and schedules (to facilitate work-life balance, afternoon training and asynchronous virtual modalities are included). Some activities are aimed at both groups, such as those related to gender perspective, digital skills, occupational risk prevention, and research projects. These common lines respond to cross-cutting areas of institutional and professional development.

September 10: The UAB promotes language learning as a path to more training, research and socialisation

The UAB offers language courses for international students studying at the UAB so that they can become familiar with the Catalan language, and also for UAB students thinking of studying abroad, to learn the language of the country they will visit. Languages are key to opening the doors of both academic learning and research activities, as well as being able to communicate in everyday life situations and understanding the local culture. The similarity among the different Romance languages also makes it easier for those who speak one of these languages, to quickly learn to speak another one. La UAB de les llengues

On the one hand, the Languages Service - UAB Idiomes offers a wide array of courses in many of the languages spoken in the countries where UAB students go to study abroad. These courses help them improve academically and live the university experience abroad to the fullest. Mastering a new language also contributes to creating more research collaborations and advancing towards a science without borders.

NYSE END-OF-MONTH STOCK REPORT

www.buysellsignals.com

Weyerhaeuser (NYSE:WY $23.0), the NYSE's 5th largest Building Materials & Fixtures company by market cap, traded between an intra-month high of $25.35 and a seven-month low of $22.57. In October its volatility (highest price minus lowest price/lowest price) of 12.3% was 1.05 times average monthly volatility of 11.8%, up from 9.9% in September and 8.8% in August. The stock fell for a second month on Friday bringing its a two-month fall to $2.87 or 11.1%.

The share price fell $1.79 (or 7.2%) in the past month to close at $23.0 on Friday October 31. Compared with the S&P 500 Index which rose 151.7 points (or 2.3%) in the month, this represented a relative price change of -9.5%.

The price ranged between a high of 25.03 on Friday, 3 Oct and a low of 23.0 on Friday, 31 Oct. In the past month the market cap has declined by $1.3 billion to $16.7 billion.

The volume was 1.2 times average trading per month of 92.1 million shares.

2.2 January 31 2022: Weyerhaeuser reports fourth quarter, record full year results

Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today reported fourth quarter net earnings of $416 million, or 55 cents per diluted share, on net sales of $2.2 billion. This compares with net earnings of $292 million, or 39 cents per diluted share, on net sales of $2.1 billion for the same period last year and net earnings of $482 million for the third quarter of 2021. Excluding a total after-tax benefit of $49 million for special items, the company reported fourth quarter net earnings of $367 million, or 49 cents per diluted share. This compares with net earnings before special items of $361 million for the same period last year and $450 million for the third quarter of 2021. Adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter of 2021 was $674 million compared with $657 million for the same period last year and $746 million for the third quarter of 2021.

For the full year 2021, Weyerhaeuser reported record net earnings of $2.6 billion, or $3.47 per diluted share, on net sales of $10.2 billion. This compares with net earnings of $797 million on net sales of $7.5 billion for the full year 2020. Full year 2021 includes a total after-tax benefit of $81 million for special items. Excluding these items, the company reported net earnings of $2.5 billion, or $3.37 per diluted share. This compares with net earnings before special items of $962 million for the full year 2020. Adjusted EBITDA for full year 2021 was a record $4.1 billion compared with $2.2 billion for full year 2020.

This morning, the company declared a $1.45 per share supplemental dividend. On a combined basis, including dividends and share repurchase, the company is returning more than $2 billion of cash, or 79 percent of 2021 Adjusted FAD, to shareholders based on our 2021 results.

"Our 2021 financial performance was the strongest on record and each of our businesses delivered exceptional results despite persistent operational and market challenges," said Devin W.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

May 22: Weyerhaeuser Acquiring High-Quality Timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia

Capitalizing on unique off-market opportunity to further enhance Southern Timberlands portfolio with highly productive and strategically located acreage

SEATTLE, May 22, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced an agreement to acquire approximately 117,000 acres of high-quality timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia from Roanoke Timberlands LLC, a subsidiary of Roseburg Forest Products, for $375 million. Comprised of mature, highly productive timberlands, the acreage will be well-integrated with existing Weyerhaeuser timberland and mill operations in North Carolina, will expand the company's footprint into attractive markets in southeastern Virginia and will offer substantial alternative value opportunities. The acquisition is expected to deliver immediate and sustained portfolio-leading cash flows within the company's Southern Timberlands business.

Key attributes of the acquisition:

Located in strong and growing sawlog and fiber markets in the U.S. South Primarily fee ownership with 81 percent planted pine acreage, strong site productivity and favorable all-weather logging operability Mature planted pine age class expected to produce an average annual harvest of 7.4 tons per acre (or 860,000 tons) over the first five years Expected to deliver an average annual timber free cash flow yield of 5.1 percent over the first five years Significant optionality to capture additional upside from real estate, natural climate solutions and natural resource opportunities "These are exceptional timberlands, and we're excited and well-positioned to capitalize on this unique off-market opportunity," said Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our unmatched timber holdings and have remained disciplined in our approach to growing the value of our timberlands - including through strategically targeted private transactions like the one we're announcing today.

May 21: Weyerhaeuser to Sell Princeton, B.C., Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Agreement with local buyer includes manufacturing facility and associated timber licenses in British Columbia

SEATTLE, May 21, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced it has reached an agreement to sell its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group, owners of Gorman Bros.Lumber Ltd., a family-owned wood products manufacturer headquartered in West Kelowna, B.C. The purchase price is approximately $120 million CAD in cash, which includes Weyerhaeuser's manufacturing facility, all associated timber license assets in British Columbia and the value of working capital, which will be subject to customary purchase price adjustments at closing.

Weyerhaeuser and Gorman Group have a long-standing relationship in Canada. Gorman Bros.Lumber is currently the Princeton mill's largest customer, and Gorman Group has operated in Canada for more than 75 years, with offices and facilities in B.C. and Washington state.

"We are grateful to all the dedicated employees who contributed to the success of our Princeton operations over the years," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer for Weyerhaeuser. "The community has always been incredibly welcoming and supportive of our mill and people, and it was important for us to sell to a local buyer with deep roots in the region. Gorman has been a great customer and strategic partner, and we believe this will be a seamless transition that will position the mill for future success in a challenging operating environment - providing long-term certainty for the mill and the broader community."

"Weyerhaeuser's Princeton operation will be a natural fit with the Gorman Group," says Nick Arkle, chief executive officer of the Gorman Group. "We've had a strong connection to the Princeton operation for many years, and we know firsthand the skill, commitment and quality that define its team.

WHAT YOU WILL FIND IN THIS MD&A

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. In general, Western log markets are highly tensioned by available supply, while Southern log markets have more available supply. However, additional mill capacity being added in the U.S.

SECTION 5 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

SECTION 11 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

11.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%].
